summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have been engaging in a public dispute. Merson initially questioned Townsend’s inclusion in the England squad, stating anyone could get in if Townsend could. Townsend then scored for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit he was wrong. However, Merson then made another critical comment about Townsend’s limited playing time for Tottenham (brought on in the 83rd minute against Burnley), which reignited the exchange.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to sign 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto this summer for a reported £4million. If the transfer is completed, Muto would initially join Chelsea’s partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, on loan. Muto has 11 international caps for Japan and has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo. The offer is not linked to Chelsea’s recent £200million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree, has not yet decided if he will accept the offer.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, particularly boys who may also grow slightly taller. Researchers suggest this may be due to antibiotics killing gut bacteria that would normally consume food, leading to increased food availability for the body and potentially increased appetite. While the study doesn’t prove causation, it suggests antibiotic use could contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic, with one in five boys and one in ten girls being overweight or obese by age two in England. Concerns also exist regarding the over-prescription of antibiotics and the development of antibiotic-resistant superbugs.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a guard slipped on a manhole cover, fell, and dropped his rifle. The incident was filmed by tourist David Meadwell and witnessed by hundreds of others. The guard quickly recovered and continued as if nothing happened, though he appeared embarrassed. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment. The Changing of the Guard draws large crowds of tourists daily, and the guards are fully operational soldiers, not just ceremonial.

In 2016, A&E networks (A&E, Lifetime, and History) will simulcast a remake of the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally had over 100 million viewers. The new version will retell the story of Kunta Kinte, an African sold into slavery in Virginia, and will draw more from Alex Haley’s novel while consulting historical scholars. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will be a co-executive producer. The remake aims to reach a new generation unfamiliar with the story, particularly in light of recent events regarding race in America.

In 1978, Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges he was assaulted by palace aides at Clarence House on his first day of work. He claims he was pinned down and groped while being pressured to participate in an orgy. His initial complaints were ignored for months, but were recently passed to Scotland Yard following inquiries into historical child sex abuse cases. The Royal Household has stated they will co-operate with the ongoing police investigation.

Jesse and Melissa Meek of Happy Valley, Oregon, announced their pregnancy with a rap video parody of the “Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” theme song, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. They conceived in two months and shared a sonogram at the end of the video, which was initially made to inform distant loved ones. Jesse is a descendant of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble was used in key scenes with Clark Gable. The auction, held by Heritage Auctions, included over 150 items from the film, part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who saved the dress from being discarded after purchasing it for $20. Other items sold included a straw hat for $52,500, a Clark Gable suit for $55,000, and a bonnet for $30,000. *Gone With the Wind* is based on a 1936 book by Margaret Mitchell, and Hattie McDaniel won an Academy Award for her role in the film.

A two-year-old boy fell into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents reportedly dangled him over the railing. He fell 10-12 feet and sustained minor bumps and bruises to his leg, and is in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. The parents rescued the child before first responders arrived, and the cheetahs did not approach him. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family and has closed the exhibit following the incident.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A non-functional speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, has been re-angled to point at a private residence. The camera stopped working in 2013 when around 300 similar cameras were decommissioned across the region due to obsolete technology. Enforcement now relies on mobile units and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the re-angled camera and will investigate, potentially removing it, but it won’t be included in upcoming digital technology pilot programs.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd. He states he is fit and ready to run, and aims to make Jamaica proud, continuing the country’s successful relay tradition. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves supported Barcelona’s basketball team in an 85-80 El Clasico win, though Real Madrid leads their Euro League division on points difference. Neymar also captained Brazil to a 1-0 win against Chile, facing tough challenges during the match. Before the international break, Barcelona won their La Liga El Clasico and are currently four points ahead, with their next match against Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble. Neymar was accompanied by his sister Rafaella at the basketball game.

Between Friday and Monday, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants attempting to reach Italy from Africa and the Middle East. There are unconfirmed reports of a capsized ship carrying 550 people with 145 rescued, though the coast guard has found no evidence of this. Italy has seen over 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first three months of 2015, with at least 480 migrant deaths in the Mediterranean Sea so far this year due to factors like bad weather and overcrowding. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, traveling through Libya.

Arsene Wenger is pleased Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over other clubs like Liverpool. Sanchez quickly became impactful, scoring 19 goals this season, and Wenger believes his rapid adaptation demonstrates his quality. Liverpool’s interest in Sanchez may have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez’s transfer to Barcelona. Wenger also acknowledged Brendan Rodgers’ success in developing Liverpool despite losing key players like Suarez and Sturridge, and downplayed any interest in Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling Hour Record—currently 52.491km set by Rohan Dennis—on June 7th at London’s Olympic Velodrome. Tickets go on sale April 19th, and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins recently finished his career with Team Sky and is also targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani in a challenging match at the Fed Cup, but the US team lost the overall tie 3-2 and was relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged she is not as prepared for the claycourt season as she believed, and the team needs to improve to return to the World Group. Despite this, Williams remains a dominant force, having won 19 grand slam singles titles.

River Plate is interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them from 2001-2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Currently on loan at Manchester United (from Monaco) where he has struggled with only 4 Premier League goals, Falcao recently performed well for Colombia, equalling their goalscoring record with 24 goals. River Plate’s vice president, Matias Patanian, stated the club "dream of Falcao" and "the doors are open" for his return.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from the 2012 series of *The X Factor*, has become the face of Batiste dry shampoo’s 2015 ‘Ready For It’ campaign. This is her first brand collaboration, facilitated by the MILES agency, and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring her single “Mirror Man”. The campaign features images of the 19-year-old singer with various hairstyles against a city backdrop. Mark Hargreaves of Crown Talent & Media Group notes the natural fit between Henderson and the brand.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres on March 14th after being confronted and “arming himself with a weapon” following a vehicle and foot pursuit—Siler was wanted on a felony warrant. A billboard thanking the community for its support, featuring Torres and his dog, was erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, causing distress to Siler’s family and friends who deem it disrespectful. Torres is on leave while Siler’s death is investigated; a previous shooting involving Torres (of Terry Knight) was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in the town of Negur. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces. The militant group Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian group operating from Balochistan, Pakistan, claimed responsibility. Iran has requested Pakistan to apprehend the surviving militants, and Pakistan is investigating the incident and has pledged to take action if the militants entered their territory. This follows a pattern of attacks by Jaish al Adal, with militants reportedly fleeing back into Pakistan after previous incidents.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the country’s Air Self-Defense Force has never encountered unidentified flying objects from outer space. This response came after a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler with a notable career in both sports and politics, who inquired about potential extraterrestrial threats and related research. Previous discussions regarding alien encounters occurred in 2007 when another Defense Minister considered the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion.

Jin Pai, 35, was hospitalised with cuts to his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China. He initially admitted to squatting on the toilet to avoid contact with the seat, but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid paying for damages. Authorities believe the incident was accidental and reminded people to sit on toilets.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, was arrested in Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom traced back to him. He is accused of sexually abusing the girl over a four-year period, beginning when she was nine, and filming her and others with the hidden camera—including showering—over three to four years. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims and specifically targeting the 15-year-old girl. He faces charges including sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy, and is being held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing on May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s photo series features daughters with serious expressions posed next to their fathers dramatically leaping in the air. The fathers, typically wearing suits, express a “fun side” through these energetic poses, as part of a project from his book, *Daughter and Salaryman*. The photos are gaining online attention for their unusual nature and are taken in front of Japanese landmarks.

Paul Downton was dismissed as England’s managing director, shifting focus to the County Championship season, but attention remains on Kevin Pietersen. Pietersen, who last played for England during a disastrous 2014 Ashes tour, has rejoined Surrey and hopes to force his way back into the Test team, now that the managing director who previously axed him has been dismissed. Surrey’s campaign begins on April 19th against Glamorgan, following a match against Oxford MCCU on Sunday.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria—for the second time in a week—due to poor results, including a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani which leaves the team near the relegation zone. He had been briefly reinstated by the club owner but was ultimately replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic. Ze Maria is a former Brazil international with 25 caps.

Radamel Falcao’s loan move to Manchester United has been unsuccessful, with only four goals scored all season despite a £46million permanent transfer option. His former teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets leaving Monaco, where he was unhappy but would have had more playing time and Champions League participation, and feels Falcao is not thriving at Manchester United. Falcao has struggled to regain his form after a serious knee injury.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A man robbed a dairy in Christchurch, New Zealand on Saturday at approximately 12:30pm. He was wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, and is described as very tall. The robber demanded cash from the owner’s daughter, taking the till and up to $1500. No weapons were used, and the suspect is still at large. Police are asking the public for information and can be contacted via Crimestoppers (0800 555 111) or online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice in March for inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old male students. She was initially arrested on March 19th for an inappropriate relationship with one student, admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. A second arrest occurred on Monday following accusations from another student alleging sexual activity in January. She was released on $50,000 bail and is currently on administrative leave from the school district.

A crocodile was filmed swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dog—belonging to a local bike shop owner—in its jaws. The video has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The crocodile held the dog for hours, and is thought to have come from a nearby sanctuary located 200m upriver. Crocodiles are common in the area due to the mangroves and can grow up to 6 meters long, increasingly leading to encounters with humans.

Hull City, managed by Steve Bruce, are fighting to avoid relegation from the Premier League following a 2-0 loss to Southampton. They currently have six wins and are two points above the drop zone with six games remaining, including difficult matches against top teams. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players but remains confident they can stay up, hoping eight or nine wins will be enough. Southampton won the match due to a penalty from James Ward-Prowse and a goal from Graziano Pelle, moving them to fifth in the league, but manager Ronald Koeman had to address a dispute over penalty-taking between players Sadio Mane and Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing and making changes to pupils’ completed SATs exams. This led to the annulment of the entire school’s 2014 SATs results. While Guffick claimed he asked pupils to improve legibility, a panel found his actions to be dishonest and unacceptable professional conduct, though not fraudulent. He has expressed remorse and accepted the allegations.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, with whom he has a son. They married in Mauritius in the previous year and have been dating since 2012. Lindegaard has struggled for playing time at Manchester United since joining in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently third-choice goalkeeper. He was linked with a move to FC Midtjylland but it did not materialize, and has been told he can leave United. Beqiri is a model with a significant Instagram following and regularly posts photos of her work.

The 13 letters that once lit up Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite being valued between $300,000 and $600,000. Current owner Reggie Jackson, who bought the letters in 2008 after the stadium’s final game, had hoped a new owner would emerge. A New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000-$30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction. The Yankee Stadium letters were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, having illuminated the Bronx since then.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke with Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding incidents involving nitrous oxide and shisha pipes, but will not discipline them. Despite past disappointments in the title race and Capital One Cup, Rodgers believes his team is prepared to reach the FA Cup final, with Steven Gerrard returning from suspension for the semi-final against Aston Villa. Rodgers emphasized the responsibilities of professional athletes and the importance of learning from setbacks.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier and posted a picture relaxing with his dog. He is expected to start in Arsenal’s upcoming match against Liverpool, having missed a previous game against Newcastle due to illness. Since January, Ozil has scored three goals and provided four assists, and feels he has adjusted well to the demands of English football, particularly the frequent matches. He was signed from Real Madrid in 2013 for £42.5million.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated the club is “very happy” with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him, despite speculation. Enrique took charge last summer with a contract until 2016 and has the team positioned to potentially win three trophies, currently six games away from winning La Liga. Barcelona recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay until 2020 and worth around £100,000 per week. He is expected to be considered for the club captaincy following Steven Gerrard’s departure. He is the third player to extend their contract under Brendan Rodgers, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. While Raheem Sterling has rejected a new deal, Liverpool expect him to remain at the club.

Filipe Luis intends to remain at Chelsea until his contract expires, despite interest from Atletico Madrid. Though he has had difficulty securing a starting position, he is happy at the club. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is pushing the team to remain focused and win their remaining nine Premier League games to secure the title. Luis recently played in friendlies for Brazil against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes’s three-match ban for a knee collision with George North’s head during a match on March 27 was overturned on appeal. Hughes was initially red-carded and suspended, but the appeal panel determined the incident was accidental and no foul play occurred. North was knocked unconscious—his third concussion in two months—and will rest for at least a month. Hughes missed a Champions Cup quarter-final due to the suspension, but is now free to play, though will likely return to action on April 26.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Recent fiery red sunsets in Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia are due to smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia. These fires, initially started by farmers, spread due to strong winds and destroyed villages before being extinguished. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific Ocean, and the smoke particles filter out colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange hues to dominate sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will become less red and air quality will improve.

Becky Schoenig’s 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri, but was recovered after a tip led police to the vehicle. The car was returned with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel, leading Schoenig to jokingly thank the thieves for “pimping” it out on Facebook. She is now having the car professionally cleaned due to cigarette and marijuana smells and is creating a smoothie named “The Sexton on Wheels” to honor the man who found her car.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League. This is due to incentivised contracts designed to meet financial fairplay requirements. Currently in fourth place, their chances are threatened by Liverpool, and their recent form has been poor, with seven losses since the start of 2015. The squad has around £12 million riding on qualifying for Europe. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admits the season has deteriorated, and the club may struggle to attract top players like Paul Pogba. Manchester United are currently four points ahead of City.

Manchester United’s Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a ‘mini-derby’ match played at Moss Lane, with a goal from Callum Gribbin via a free-kick. The match featured a high number of English and Mancunian players (13 of 22). United’s win puts them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both play-off series matches. The game showcased skilled and committed young players, potentially deserving of future first-team opportunities.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Following a 1-1 draw with Italy, England's Joe Hart (age not specified, but 10 years younger than Buffon) praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th international cap. Hart also celebrated his own 50th cap for England and expressed his desire to continue playing for both his club and country. He views Buffon as an inspiration and continues to learn from watching him.

Chipotle is partnering with Postmates to offer delivery in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion food delivery market. This will include a 9% service charge, with Postmates delivery fees starting at $5. Other restaurants like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also expanding into food delivery. Chipotle has recently seen visits from presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton.

Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, which killed three people including 8-year-old Martin Richard, and wounded over 200. His sentencing phase begins Tuesday and is expected to last four weeks. Martin Richard’s parents, Bill and Denise Richard, are advocating for the Justice Department to remove the death penalty from consideration in exchange for a life sentence without parole and a waiver of appeals, to prevent years of further reliving the trauma for their family and other victims. Tsarnaev’s brother, Tamerlan, was killed in a shootout with police.

A billionaire purchased a Boeing 747 jumbo jet for £400 million and had it customized over three years into a luxury home and private plane. While typically holding 600 passengers, this version accommodates a single owner and dozens of guests, featuring bedrooms (including eight beds in an “aeroloft”), multiple lounges, a restaurant with a kitchen, a dining room, a conference room, and office space. The interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station with a successful ascent. While the Dragon is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies (including an espresso maker) and will return with around 3,000 pounds of materials, SpaceX’s attempt to land the first stage of the rocket on a droneship was unsuccessful – the rocket landed but tipped over. This is SpaceX’s sixth mission to the ISS, and they aim to reuse rockets to significantly reduce the cost of space travel. The launch was initially scheduled for Monday but delayed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, launched in collaboration with NBC's *Today* show. An Elvis-obsessed couple, to be announced next Monday, will win a free wedding on April 23rd at the Westgate Hotel (formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed over 830 shows), including a reception, hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets. Priscilla Presley has emphasized this is a first-class experience and will not allow Elvis impersonators. The chapel is also the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside of Memphis. Couples entered by submitting videos or photos explaining why they deserve to win.

Liverpool defeated Newcastle United 2-0, with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen. This win came after disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Liverpool, currently four points behind Manchester City, believe they can still catch City in the Premier League race. Both Jordan Henderson and Simon Mignolet have played a record-tying 47 games this season. Newcastle appealed for a penalty that was not awarded.

Roma defeated Napoli 1-0 in a Serie A match, ending a four-month home winless streak. Miralem Pjanic scored the winning goal in the 25th minute. Roma now leads Lazio by four points, while Napoli extended their winless streak to five games. The match had heightened security due to past incidents between fans, but no problems were reported. Roma played without injured players Francesco Totti and Gervinho, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was crucial in securing the win.

Certainly! Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a goalless draw in their League One match at Keepmoat Stadium. The game was uninspiring, reflecting Doncaster's mid-table season performance. The match had so little action that the highlights video created by Doncaster's media team was only 27 seconds long, including just 14 seconds of actual game play (the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle).

Roland Giroux has a unique relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan around 1986. He interacts with the fish through touch, stroking and massaging it for at least 15 minutes daily. The fish actively seeks out this interaction, returning to Giroux’s hand for continued petting and appearing saddened when he stops. Giroux initially bonded with the fish by hand-feeding it and removed tankmates who were bullying it, leading to the fish becoming more sociable.

Ben Stokes is a fiery and valuable player for the England cricket team, known for his aggression—illustrated by past incidents like breaking his wrist punching a locker and confrontations with opponents. While his exuberance is appreciated, especially in a game sometimes lacking personality, England’s coach Peter Moores is carefully managing him to ensure his aggression is channeled productively into scoring runs and taking wickets. England wants to maximize Stokes’ playing time to help him reach his full potential, alongside Chris Jordan, and are prepared to accept both highs and lows as he develops.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12th at the Cardiff City Stadium is sold out (33,000 tickets). Both teams have 11 points in Group B, with Belgium currently leading on goal difference. Wales is in its best position to qualify for a major tournament since 1958, following a 3-0 win against Israel. The team prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium, and UEFA rules prevented a venue change to the Millennium Stadium.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

John Peacock has announced England's squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. England are the defending champions. They are in Group D with Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland, beginning their campaign against Italy on May 7th. The squad includes players from several Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea’s Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal’s Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi; with Chris Willock and the Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold recently being called up.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is highly regarded as a top youth talent. He previously rejected Barcelona’s academy to focus on his studies. City has discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht's chairman to potentially secure the player, with manager Manuel Pellegrini aiming to build for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort and Mexican national, was found dead in a Fulham flat at the end of March from injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man has been arrested and bailed in connection with her death. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her before her death, as she worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami.

Dawn, who has experienced seven miscarriages, accused her housemate Jamie of stealing £207 that was saved for a £500 gravestone for her son, Daniel James. A lie detector test on *The Jeremy Kyle Show* confirmed Jamie took the money, despite initially denying it and later blaming his girlfriend, Carol. Dawn was deeply upset by the betrayal.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis (between 217 and 228 according to reports) – primarily women, children, the ill, and the elderly – who had been captured when ISIS overtook their towns in northern Iraq last summer. Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, and the freed Yazidis were taken to Irbil by the Peshmerga. This follows previous releases of Yazidis, largely children and the elderly, since ISIS attacked their towns, causing a humanitarian crisis and widespread persecution of the Yazidi people, a religious minority of Kurdish descent.

Harry Kane has had a remarkable season, breaking into the first team for Tottenham and the England national team. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animation by Copa90, featuring his best goals and celebrations, has been released ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday, where he is competing against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the PFA Player of the Year award.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers remaining as Liverpool manager despite a trophy-less season and likely failure to qualify for the Champions League. Carragher believes Rodgers needs to identify areas for improvement and make the right signings. He also received a Beacon Award for his community work through the 23 Foundation, providing coaching to children in Merseyside.

Four-year-old James Hayward had a plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport as it was deemed a security risk after being detected on an X-ray machine. He was also frisked by security. His father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security check as “ludicrous” but did not argue due to time constraints before their flight to Lanzarote. The airport offered to post the toy back to the family, and James received a replacement toy upon their return. The airport stated they follow government regulations prohibiting items resembling prohibited items, including replica guns.

A 31-year-old man named Rich, living in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a detailed advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He offered benefits like accommodation, potentially a company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership, in exchange for a partner who is fit, attractive, a non-smoker/drinker, reliable, honest, loyal, good with housework, cooking, and intimate relations. He describes himself as athletic, tattooed, and financially stable, and is open to “reasonable offers.” He also stated former partners need not apply.

Greg Dyke, the Football Association chairman, is proposing changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve, and redefine “home-grown” as training in England before age 18 (previously 21). These proposals face opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers – Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren – support Dyke’s plans, warning that failing to increase English talent will hinder future success, as only 36.8% of recent Premier League starters were eligible for England selection. They believe promising young players like Kane, Barkley, Sterling need more opportunities.

Demelza Poldark has given birth to a baby daughter, and Ross Poldark is shown to be a loving father. The timeline of her pregnancy has been very fast-paced, progressing from announcement to eight months pregnant, and then birth, within a single episode and a short timeframe. Fans have noted this rapid progression, comparing it to a previous pregnancy storyline in the show. Ross Poldark is a popular character, but is committed to Demelza.

Leicester City, currently bottom of the Barclays Premier League but three points from safety after back-to-back wins (including a 3-2 victory against West Brom with a winning goal by Jamie Vardy), are urged by manager Nigel Pearson to focus on their own performance and not on the results of their relegation rivals. Pearson wants the team to control their own destiny and maintain focus during the final games of the season.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, completed the longest recorded mammal migration of nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 kilometers). She traveled from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous record of 10,190 miles held by a humpback whale. This journey suggests Varvara may be an eastern gray whale, challenging previous classifications and potentially impacting the estimated population of the endangered western gray whale (currently believed to be 150).

Approximately 1,000ft of seabed rose to the surface off the east coast of Japan’s Hokkaido Island near the town of Rausu, creating a new stretch of coastline. This was caused by a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, and the land rose as high as 50ft in some areas. Locals reported no prior indication of the movement—no sounds or tremors were felt—and authorities do not anticipate further expansion of the new landmass. Marine life remains on the newly emerged land. It is not connected to the recent earthquake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel has stated he wants to stay at Paris Saint-Germain despite a recent disagreement with his manager, Laurent Blanc, over being left out of a Champions League game. He expressed his happiness with the club, city, and teammates, and desires to sign a new contract. However, the club is also interested in signing Dani Alves, which may affect Van der Wiel’s future with PSG.

Carlos Tevez wants to leave Juventus to return to Boca Juniors, his former club in Argentina. While his contract with Juventus runs until 2016, Boca is close to a deal contingent on Tevez terminating his current contract. Juventus has accepted his desire to leave and is seeking replacements, despite Tevez being the league’s top scorer with 17 goals this season. His move will not affect his position with the Argentinian national team.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, securing a place in the Champions League semi-finals despite Porto’s initial two-goal lead from the first leg (3-1). During the match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola ripped his trousers, exposing his underwear, and also removed his blazer—an incident he joked about after the game. Goals were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski (who scored twice).

This passage discusses the need for more **Changing Places toilets** in the UK to support people with severe disabilities and their carers. Currently, there are 893 in the UK, but over a quarter of a million people require these facilities, which are larger and better equipped than standard accessible toilets (12 square metres vs 3.3 square metres). 

While **Changing Places guidelines are currently only a recommendation** in building regulations (since 2009), campaigners are advocating for them to be **made compulsory** in larger, new buildings like shopping centres and stadiums. This is due to the stress and indignity faced by individuals and families who struggle to find suitable facilities, sometimes being forced to change loved ones on unsanitary surfaces. 

Businesses face logistical and financial challenges with installation, but examples like **Arsenal Football Club** demonstrate successful adaptation and positive public response. The lack of compulsory regulations creates uncertainty for designers, who prioritize legal requirements over recommendations.

A House of Lords report examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While many fishers hope Brexit will allow greater control of UK waters and boost exports, the report warns that continued access to the EU market may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. The industry, though small (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 workers), must not be marginalized in negotiations. In 2013, Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has extensive access to individual’s online data, including chat logs, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. This access was achieved through programs like Prism, which allowed “backdoor” access to servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Google, Facebook, and Apple (though these companies deny involvement). The US government defends these practices as necessary for national security and preventing terrorism, stating that law-abiding citizens have nothing to fear. However, concerns have been raised regarding privacy, with Snowden stating he acted due to “horrifying” surveillance practices, and the EU seeking further details. Despite a brain injury initially taking his speech, he now speaks unaided and dedicates his time to gym/rehab and charity work for military causes, including being a patron of Pilgrim Bandits. In 2011, the US poverty rate remained at 15% (46.2 million people), despite previous years of increases. Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, has signed a deal to stay with Lancashire until 2019 after joining from Somerset in 2013. Ashley Giles highlights his talent and contribution to the team's T20 Blast win, as well as his positive influence in the dressing room. Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are currently in Portsmouth Harbour and are being sold. Bids were due January 23rd, with viewings in February/March and a final decision expected in the spring. The government aims to have at least one ship recycled in the UK to assess industry capacity, while also seeking the best financial return. There were no proposals submitted to preserve the ships, but some bidders are finalizing offers. There is interest in potentially using one as a reef/diving attraction. Since 1987, Fiji has experienced political instability due to racial tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians (descendants of Indian labourers). This has resulted in four coups (1987, 2000, 2006, and a bloodless takeover), harming the economy—particularly tourism—and its international reputation, leading to a Commonwealth suspension in 2009. While originally of equal numbers, Indo-Fijians have emigrated due to the unrest, creating a slight indigenous Fijian majority. Despite a diverse economy reliant on sugar and tourism, Fiji faces trade and budget deficits and is a major aid recipient. Elections were held in 2014, leading to the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji’s re-instatement into the Commonwealth.

Syria is working to comply with the timetable for destroying its declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, but missed a recent deadline for full handover. Shipments of weapons have been attacked, hindering progress – only 4% (30 tonnes) has left the country so far.

Russia expects the transfer of weapons to the coast to be completed by March 1st, with full destruction by the end of June, though the OPCW acknowledges security concerns are slowing the process. Syria maintains its commitment to these agreements.

The Booker Prize is in its 46th year and is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality, for the first time. The 2014 shortlist includes Mukherjee’s *The Lives of Others* (the current favourite at 5/2), Howard Jacobson (*J*), Ali Smith (*How To Be Both*), Joshua Ferris (*To Rise Again at a Decent Hour*), Karen Joy Fowler (*We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* – the best-selling shortlisted novel with over 55,000 copies sold), and Richard Flanagan (*The Narrow Road to the Deep North*). The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London’s Guildhall and will receive £2,500. Last year’s winner was Eleanor Catton.

Fosse Park, a retail park opened in 1989 and purchased for £345.5m in August, is set for improvements. Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people require an HMO license, costing around £1,000, though fines for operating without one can reach £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs exist in their area. National licensing applies to properties three storeys or more with five or more unrelated occupants. Following a recent election resulting in Fine Gael (50 seats), Fianna Fáil (44 seats), Sinn Féin (23 seats), and the Labour Party (7 seats), no majority government has been formed. The Sorrento ferry caught fire approximately 27km from Mallorca while travelling to Valencia. All passengers and crew were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by the ferry Puglia. Researchers are examining the sheep for signs of premature aging and age-related diseases like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes, as the cloning process *may* transfer “age-memory” to the clone. The original Dolly died at 6.5 years old with osteoarthritis, prompting this further research to determine if her death was due to bad luck or a flaw in the cloning process itself. Initial findings suggest the sheep are currently in good health as they approach 9-10 years old, and the study’s results will be published soon.

Shutter Speed won, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three-quarters, and will race next in Chantilly rather than the Epsom Oaks—where stablemates Enable and Coronet will compete. Teenie, a one-year-old cat, was shot three times with an air weapon – twice in the shoulder and once in the back leg, resulting in an amputation. Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term contract, making him their second most expensive signing after selling Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. A study of 671 schools found that while tablet use is increasing – present in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with a projected rise from 430,000 to 900,000 devices between 2014-2016 – there's no clear evidence of academic improvement linked to their use. The “Growing Up in the City” exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs documenting children’s lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis process to improve survival rates, which were previously poor compared to other European countries. The new system uses three routes: fast-tracking patients with obvious symptoms, diagnosis centers for those with unclear symptoms, and “yes-no” centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes, implemented since 2007, have improved organization, reduced wait times, and led to better cancer survival rates, with potential lessons for Wales’ similar health system.

The Swansea Bay tidal lagoon project is facing disagreement over its potential impact on fish populations. Cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire are dying after ingesting a toxic substance, confirmed by tests. His career began unconventionally – after a period of surfing and service in the Vietnam War, he pursued research following medical training. He revolutionized gene sequencing by focusing on RNA rather than the entire genome, and founded Celera Genomics to privately map the human genetic code, competing with the public project. This success, and his subsequent ventures, have made him a wealthy scientist independent of traditional funding sources, now focused on projects like ocean microbe genome sequencing and utilizing synthetic microbes for environmental benefits.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker currently playing for Spain in Euro 2016, began his career at Real Madrid (10 goals in his first team debut at 18) before moving to Juventus in 2014. Tesco, the third largest retailer globally, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a private equity firm. This person experienced racial abuse but overcame it. They considered representing France but are now focused on winning a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. A guide to getting into martial arts is also available.

Between the late 1960s/early 1970s and the late 2000s, glacial coverage in the French Alps decreased from approximately 375 sq km to 275 sq km – a 26% loss over 40 years. This retreat, mirroring trends in other parts of the Alps (Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, Germany, France, and Italy), is not uniform; it is more significant in the southern Alps due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions (less precipitation and cloud cover) compared to the north. The research, conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie, utilized map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual inspection to ensure accuracy.

Scotland’s women’s team has won all five of their qualifiers and a win against Iceland would likely secure their place in the finals. Peta is requesting Skegness replace its mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish mascot and the slogan “Skegness - A Happy Plaice”, arguing the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty. The mayor welcomes suggestions but believes there is little support for removing the Jolly Fisherman, stating it is seen as happy and friendly and effectively promotes the town. Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from the US facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after being held since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban (charges he denies). A US review panel determined he was no longer a “continuing significant threat.” He will now enter a rehabilitation centre in Kuwait for at least a year. His release reduces the Guantanamo Bay inmate count to 148, and he is the first to be freed since May. The facility opened in January 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has sought to close it.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, specifically the Gallipoli landings. Services were held at Hyde Park Corner, Westminster Abbey, and the Cenotaph, including a parade with veterans and their families. These events honour the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand service members in all wars, and were first commemorated in London in 1916 with King George V. The Gallipoli campaign was a bloody, eight-month attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Clarkson, age 30, recently rejoined Premiership Well and is set to potentially debut for St Mirren against Alloa this Saturday. He previously scored nine goals for Dundee and has maintained his fitness through playing in games and training. He has nearly 400 senior appearances across several clubs including Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers, and has been capped twice for Scotland. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa, and Clarkson hopes to help the team improve their position in the league.

Ranjit Boparan purchased the turkey firm Bernard Matthews. Unite received guarantees that existing worker pension agreements will be honoured, though the final salary scheme closed in 2004. Boparan intends to restore the business to profitability through investment, cost savings, and diversifying production to include chicken processing.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The new Cowes chain ferry has experienced a problematic launch since May 14th, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension due to training issues, also causing damage to cars. The ferry crossing is currently free until July 2nd while the council reviews the project and gathers feedback. Local businesses are suffering due to the disruption and are seeking compensation, which is under discussion. The council views the issues as “teething problems” for a prototype and has taken steps to address them, including ramp extensions and seamanship training.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A House of Lords report examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While many fishers hope Brexit will allow greater control of UK waters and boost exports, the report warns that continued access to the EU market may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. The industry, though small (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 workers), must not be marginalized in negotiations. Key issues include shared fish stocks, the need for continued market access, and potential divergence in fisheries management between the four UK nations. Recent EU quota increases are viewed optimistically by some in the industry. The government aims for both market access and fairer fisheries management.

Timothy Geaney was removed from the teaching register after admitting to possessing or allowing the taking of images of young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a sex offender program. The General Teaching Council Scotland determined his actions were incompatible with being a teacher, demonstrated a pattern of behaviour, and posed a risk of re-offending. He is prohibited from re-registering as a teacher for two years.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A fire on March 2nd at a Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited site in Duncan Street disrupted train services and led to travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) has revoked the company’s environmental permit, effective August 7th (subject to appeal), and suspended their waste acceptance. While generally compliant with fire safety laws (according to the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service - GMFRS), concerns were raised about the potential impact of a fire, prompting joint visits with the EA. The cause of the fire is currently unknown, and the company must remove all waste from the site. The site was run by Asset and Land Group, who could not be contacted for comment.

Syria is working to comply with the timetable for destroying its declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, but missed a recent deadline for full handover. Only about 4% (30 tonnes) of the stockpile has left the country, causing concern that the UN-backed plan is falling behind schedule. Shipments of weapons have been attacked, and the Syrian government blames “terrorist groups” for hindering the process and for attacks using barrel bombs in Aleppo, resulting in numerous deaths including children. The government denies these accusations and claims to be defending against terrorists. Fighting continues over Aleppo's central prison, with conflicting reports of control – the Syrian government claims to have thwarted an attack, while rebel groups claim full control. Russia expects the transfer of weapons to the coast to be completed by March 1st, with full destruction by the end of June.

England defeated Pakistan at Old Trafford by a large margin, leveling the four-match series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his scores of 254 and 71, as well as contributions in the field. England set a target of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Pakistan’s batting struggled, with only their captain and Asad Shafiq scoring over 50 in the first two tests, and they were bowled out for 198 and 234. Both teams next play on Friday, with Pakistan facing Worcestershire and England preparing for the third Test on August 3rd.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in Welsh residential care. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, care providers, and staff to develop recommendations for improvement. The review will focus on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, with the goal of ensuring a good quality of life for residents. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but is critical of the lack of care provider representation on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, formerly player-manager of Arbroath (since 2010), has been appointed as the new manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. He previously played for Aberdeen and other Scottish clubs, and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap. While managing Arbroath, who were relegated to League Two in 2014, he led them to win the Scottish Third Division title in 2011 – their first national trophy. Aberdeen’s chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a thorough search, and Arbroath were understanding of Sheerin’s desire to return to Aberdeen.

Following Bob Bradley’s sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea’s match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as their first choice. There is concern about the difficulty of promotion from the Championship should Swansea be relegated, citing its increased competitiveness. The club has seemingly lost its identity ("Swansea Way") since Michael Laudrup’s departure in 2014, and questions remain about replacing key players, despite Curtis believing the current squad can avoid relegation. The club has a history of rising from near bankruptcy to Premier League promotion in 2011.

J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who accelerated human genome mapping, initially facing criticism from the scientific community. He later led the creation of the first synthetic life form, *Synthia*, through the J Craig Venter Institute. His drive stems from experiences during the Vietnam War, where he was a hospital orderly. Venter revolutionized gene sequencing by focusing on RNA rather than the entire genome, and founded Celera Genomics to privately map the human genetic code – a project completed alongside the public effort in 2001. He continues to pursue genetic research, including a project to sequence ocean microbes, and believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industry and environmental efforts.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A Sutton Trust report finds that many English apprenticeships are low quality and short compared to those in countries like Germany, where vocational education is highly regarded. Currently, most apprenticeships in England are below A-level standard (level three) and are taken up by those already employed and over 25. There is high competition—11 young people for each apprenticeship.

The report recommends a radical expansion of apprenticeships (up to 300,000 new starts yearly), prioritizing level three and above, lasting at least three years, and limiting level two apprenticeships to 10%. The Department for Education states they are reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, and the Association of Colleges acknowledges the need for improvement while also advocating for the preservation of some existing, respected programs.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze), won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska. She aims to win a 17th title in Saturday’s road race and is targeting success at the 2016 Rio Paralympics. Storey initially competed in swimming, winning medals since 1992, before transitioning to cycling in 2005, and has now earned 21 world titles across both sports.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference due to failing to meet deadlines to pay football creditors a debt of £148,000, and overall debts of approximately £225,000 including £70,000 to HMRC. Despite a last-minute takeover by Tommy Agombar and offers from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club, assurances to the Conference were not met. Chester, who were previously relegated, will take Hereford’s place. The club’s financial difficulties have worsened since relegation from the Football League in 2012, with falling attendance figures contributing to the problem.

Certainly! Here's a concise summary of the passage:

James Milner, age 30, earned 61 senior England caps between 2009 and his retirement, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships (with limited play in Euro 2016). He also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46) and scored one international goal against Moldova in 2014. He has stated his support for the future success of the England team under Sam Allardyce.

Christopher Hogwood, a highly influential figure in the early-music movement and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, has died following a several-month illness. He worked with leading orchestras worldwide, directed the AAM for 30 years, and was known for recordings like his 1980 *Messiah*. He also held teaching positions at several universities and was remembered for his generosity and dedication to historically informed music. A private funeral will be held, with a memorial service planned for a later date.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs was removed from mainstream school in June but has been unable to find a place in a special school, despite his mother giving up her job to care for him. All special schools in his area are at full capacity. While a local school has employed an extra assistant with the hope he can attend soon, his mother fears other families will face the same issue due to oversubscribed schools. The Education Authority is reviewing special school placement needs, with changes expected from 2016, but declined to comment on this specific case to protect the child’s privacy.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is bidding to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and Rodney Parade, viewing it as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease for Rodney Parade until 2023, with fixture priority if they remain in the Football League, and expects this contract to be honoured. A vote on the WRU takeover is scheduled for May 9th. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. Newport County is currently fighting to avoid relegation from League Two, and relegation would be a significant setback for the club and the city.

This passage details the life story of an individual who was a child soldier in Sierra Leone’s civil war (1991-2002) and later became a key figure in combating the Ebola crisis in 2014. Kidnapped at age 15 by the RUF rebels, he was forced to commit atrocities under the influence of drugs. After escaping and facing hardship, he found support through a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, which encouraged his education and rehabilitation. He then dedicated himself to public service, leading efforts to educate over 10,000 people about Ebola, provide support to 11,000 affected individuals, and establish an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives. The country was declared free of the virus after it killed almost 4,000 people in the country over the past 18 months. He now focuses on investing in young people to build a better future for Sierra Leone and the world.

A collection of 80,000 artworks belonging to the Wedgwood Museum, which was at risk of being auctioned to cover pension debts from Waterford Wedgwood plc’s 2009 collapse, has been saved by a successful fundraising campaign. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, but it will remain on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire.

Wright is set to buy 20% of Billericay Football Club and become a director, though details are still being finalised. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. The club is owned by Glenn Tamplin, who invests £10,000 weekly, and recently signed Paul Konchesky. Wright previously played non-league football for clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool early in the game, but Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester from a corner. Both teams had further chances to score, with several saves made by Blackpool’s goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, and Colchester hitting the bar. Colchester finished the match with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off with a red card for a bad tackle.

Fawley Waterside developers plan to transform the disused Fawley Power Station—which operated from 1971 to 2013 and could power one million homes—into a “merchant city” development centered around its 198-meter chimney, the tallest structure of its kind south of London’s Shard. The £1bn plan includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with building potentially starting in 2018. The 300-acre site was purchased in 2016, and the developers intend to preserve the chimney as a key feature.

Great Britain (GB) won one bronze medal in the men's omnium at the Hong Kong championships, earned by Latham. Italy beat GB in the men's team pursuit for the bronze medal, and GB’s women’s team pursuit finished fifth, failing to compete for a medal. Joe Truman was unsuccessful in the men's keirin, and Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint, but will compete in further events. The women’s team pursuit squad, comprised of young riders, showed promise despite not medalling.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in *EastEnders* to reunite with his on-screen mother, Barbara Windsor, as her character Peggy Mitchell faces her final episodes due to cancer. Peggy returned to the show to inform her son Phil of her illness and will die in the spring. The reunion of the Mitchell brothers is intended to be a significant and emotional storyline for the show.

Sadio Mane scored twice for Liverpool in a match against Tottenham, who Pochettino believes lacked desire and are struggling away from home against top-six teams. Pochettino stated that if Chelsea win their next match and go 12 points ahead, it will be a “big problem” for the title race. Spurs have only won once in their last 17 away games against top-six opponents, and appeared unprepared to fight for the Premier League title in the first half of the match, according to Pochettino. Danny Murphy noted a significant difference in Spurs’ performance at home versus away, and suggested they should revert to a back three formation when playing strong opponents.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential poll last month, now holds only eight governorships, primarily in the south-east. Muhammadu Buhari of the APC will be inaugurated on May 29th. While the APC gained ground in the north and Lagos, it did not win any of Nigeria’s five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge to Buhari’s presidency due to potential disruption of oil revenue. The elections experienced violence, though overall were more peaceful than previous years, and were impacted by factors like ethnic differences and corruption allegations against the PDP.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19-22. Attendees can use an app for augmented reality access to online content like videos and interviews. This year’s performers include The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan. The app also allows those not attending to experience the festival remotely and access information/tickets.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Following Ofsted reports alleging a “Trojan Horse” plot to impose a hardline Muslim ideology, the funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary academies—both rated “inadequate”—will be terminated. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School face potential funding loss unless concerns are addressed, including issues of segregation, unequal treatment of non-Muslims, and a narrow curriculum. A head teacher reported feeling isolated and undermined by parents during an Ofsted inspection. The reports highlighted inadequate safeguarding, unvetted speakers (including one with extremist views), and a “culture of fear and intimidation” within the schools. Parents have criticised the reports, alleging bias and accusing inspectors of having “loaded questions” and “own agendas”.

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test. Eye specialist Honey Rose is accused of gross negligence manslaughter due to allegedly failing to detect a dangerous swelling during the test and failing to refer him for further investigation; this failure allegedly led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increased pressure in his skull, and ultimately, his death. The prosecution argues his death was preventable had Ms. Rose performed her job competently, and her conduct was “criminal” due to the risk of death involved. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he met online between September 2013 and September 2014, and of sending sexually explicit material to her family on Christmas Day 2014. He was placed on the sex offenders register and his case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to the court’s greater sentencing powers. Despite being a first offender, he was assessed as posing a moderate risk of re-offending. The woman felt “blackmailed” by Weatherhogg.

Ireland scored 165-5 against Afghanistan’s 171-4, resulting in an Afghan victory with two overs to spare. Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and William Porterfield (39) contributed to Ireland’s score, while Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) led Afghanistan. Ireland’s Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck early in the innings, and Boyd Rankin is out due to a back problem. The teams will play again on Friday.

Barcelona made a supplementary tax payment of €13,550,830.56 due to potential differing interpretations of tax obligations related to Neymar’s signing. The total cost of Neymar, including fees and wages, is £106.8m, despite an initial reported fee of £48.6m (57m euros). This follows accusations of misappropriated funds and an ongoing investigation into the transfer, leading to the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell who denies wrongdoing. Despite the payment, it is not yet confirmed if the investigation will be dropped. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15th. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (both 21), are suspects and have allegedly confessed to murder, rape, and robbery, facing a possible death penalty. UK police visited Thailand at the request of the UK Foreign Office—who expressed concerns about DNA verification and suspect mistreatment—to review the investigation and are now returning to the UK to compile a report for the families. Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds; DNA found on Witheridge reportedly matches the suspects.

Scotland’s women’s team is on the verge of qualifying for the finals in the Netherlands, having won all five of their qualifiers so far. A win against Iceland, currently ranked one place above them, would almost guarantee their place. This qualification would be significant as the team has previously failed in play-off attempts for the Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup. Several players on the team play for clubs internationally, including Bayern Munich (where Evans plays) and teams in England, Sweden, and the United States, which Evans believes benefits the national team’s development.

Apple has implemented a new two-step verification process for iCloud to combat the theft of user data, prompted by recent celebrity photo hacks linked to software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. This process requires a code sent to a trusted device or via the Find My iPhone app *after* a user enters their password on a new device, blocking access without the code. Users also have a 14-character recovery key as a backup. While currently optional, experts suggest it should be the default setting, as passwords alone are vulnerable. Apple plans to encourage more users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, but concerns remain about the usability and security of the recovery key.

During the campaign period of January 23rd to May 22nd, UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Tories £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, and Labour £1,027,339. The Green Party spent £534,249 and the SNP £267,372, bringing the total spending of the top six parties to £9,347,087. All parties except Labour increased their spending compared to the 2009 election. UKIP spent 68p per vote, Labour 26p, the Conservatives 79p, and the Lib Dems £1.45 per vote. The Lib Dems lost 11 of their 12 MEPs.

Anderson, 27, left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival and may play against his former club on February 18th. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to the team’s boss, Kevin Nicholson, by Micky Adams and his move is pending international clearance. The team is currently four points above relegation and has won one of their last six games. Nicholson describes Anderson as a leader and Keating as a hungry, young player.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare occurrence even in healthy horses. While the horse had previously shown symptoms of overheating and post-race ataxia, it had never collapsed before, and no such symptoms were present on the day of the race. He was a previous winner of the Gold Cup trial (2015) and Hennessy Gold Cup (2014), and was described by his trainer as the "horse of a lifetime".

Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Alex Salmond are departing as MSPs before the 5 May election. Salmond, First Minister from 2007-2014, stated Scotland is diverse, not divided, and advocated for greater parliamentary responsibility. McNeil cautioned Holyrood to learn from Westminster regarding accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie is also leaving Holyrood, making lighthearted remarks about a colleague.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The live-action “Beauty and the Beast” film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming in May 2016 at Shepperton Studios and will be released on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will play Gaston, Josh Gad will play LeFou, Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and the role of Mrs. Potts will be played by a currently unnamed star (previously voiced by Angela Lansbury).

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet with relatives of the 96 football fans who died in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster at 11:00 BST to reveal their decision on potential charges. This follows new inquests concluding the fans were unlawfully killed and the referral of files on 23 suspects – 15 related to the disaster’s causes and 8 to police conduct afterward – to the CPS in January. Families are seeking accountability after a long struggle.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced “numerous incidents” of packages being thrown over the wall, containing contraband like mobile phones and drugs. Residents nearby have witnessed this happening, and the prison is holding a meeting to discuss safety. While a former inmate claims drones are used, the Ministry of Justice has no evidence of this. New laws allow for up to two years in jail for smuggling packages into the prison. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges more needs to be done to prevent contraband from entering the facility.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, in December. Wright admits hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the sun when he failed to stop at a red light. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care, and Wright has expressed remorse for his actions. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games in April due to veterinary medicine studies, with exams in May. She recently competed in the World Athletics Championships, finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, setting a personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March and believes she has potential for multiple future Olympics.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party. A search is currently underway in a three-acre woodland area in Chapelizod, Dublin, expected to take several weeks. A review of the case, including enhanced CCTV footage, shows Mr. Deely speaking to an unidentified man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland and being followed by the same man on Haddington Road; police are still appealing for this man to come forward.

Del Potro (ranked 165th) defeated Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in a Grand Slam match after a two-year injury absence due to wrist operations. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. 

Additionally, Nick Kyrgios defeated Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 and will play Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with a potential last 16 match against Andy Murray or John Millman.

Other winners included Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Both Tunisia and Morocco faced issues regarding their participation in the Africa Cup of Nations. Morocco had a ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport after being replaced as hosts of the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion from the 2017 tournament after lodging complaints about a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, but this was resolved following an apology to CAF. Both nations are now set to compete in the 2017 qualifying rounds; Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

McLaren, a historically successful Formula 1 team with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a period of decline. After a slump beginning in 2013 due to chassis design issues, current problems stem from the Honda power-unit despite improvements to the car itself. The team, featuring world champions Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton (previously), has faced scandals (including a $100m fine in 2007 and ‘lie-gate’ in 2009) and a cycle of triumph and decline throughout its history. Team principal Ron Dennis believes success will return, citing improvements to the car and anticipated Honda engine upgrades, but currently, the team relies on belief to restore its reputation and potentially deliver a championship for Alonso.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven. Police found people at the bar with till receipts indicating alcohol service until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. License holder Colleen O'Neill (43) and James Thomas (44) were charged with serving alcohol outside of licensed hours; O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000. The judge noted O'Neill had a poor record and the bar was operating improperly.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season (previously 272) by scoring 45 points and leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Klay Thompson scored 26 points in the win. In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, led by Pau Gasol’s 16 points and 15 rebounds, and a significant second-half comeback after being down 19 points at halftime. Dwyane Wade shot poorly for the Heat, going 4 for 20.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised by YouTube star Bas van Velzen, who they were initially told was a competition winner there for a masterclass. Van Velzen then showcased his impressive free-kick skills, “wowing” the Liverpool players. Van Velzen enjoys a following on YouTube for his free-kick videos and enjoyed pretending to be unskilled in front of the players, enjoying their reactions to his accurate shots. He also revealed Balotelli’s famous slogan t-shirt from a previous game.

Women carrying the BRCA1 gene mutation can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer—by over 60%—by having their ovaries removed (oophorectomy). A study of 676 patients showed a 20-year survival rate of 77.4%, with oophorectomy linked to a 62% reduction in breast cancer deaths for BRCA1 carriers. This benefit was most apparent for those with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer and was seen immediately after diagnosis, lasting up to 15 years. BRCA1/2 gene carriers face a lifetime risk of 50-80% of developing breast cancer. Genetic testing is available for these mutations, which are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population.

On Easter morning, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak train no. 80 (the Carolinian) in Durham, North Carolina, while on the tracks. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, experienced a delay of approximately two hours and 45 minutes, during which one passenger received medical treatment for an illness. Authorities report no other injuries to the 166 passengers. The couple may have been experiencing homelessness.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as a DEA informant for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. Despite his crucial role in taking down figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and aiding in the prosecution of Manuel Noriega, he was never granted citizenship and is now facing deportation. The DEA refused to help him after he publicized his situation, and he fears for his life if returned to Colombia. He is currently living in the US illegally and is attempting to obtain a green card or passport.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The US internet address regulator, ICANN, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices related to the new '.sucks' domain name. Vox Populi is selling '.sucks' domains (like youtube.sucks and bankofamerica.sucks) to trademark holders and celebrities at high prices – around $2,499 a year – to remove them, with Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift among those who have paid to do so. ICANN initially approved the domain but is now reconsidering due to complaints that it's a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory," as Vox Populi threatens to later offer the domains to the general public for $10 a year.

In 1988, the body of a baby boy was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk.
