The case remained unsolved for 27 years until DNA analysis of remains exhumed in 2023 led police to the baby’s mother. She was initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she revealed the baby was stillborn and the pregnancy was concealed. No foul play was determined in two post-mortem examinations and an inquest. The baby was reburied with the name Peter, after the local church, thanks to a donation from a stillbirth support group. The mother remains on bail while authorities consider charges related to failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial.

In 2010, Kristopher Hicks, then 23, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi in Bath, Somerset. The taxi driver, Michael Young, mistakenly believed Hicks intended to avoid paying the fare and drove him back to the taxi rank to “teach him a lesson,” unlawfully imprisoning him. Hicks jumped from the car, travelling over 20mph, and now requires 24-hour care. The High Court ruled Young liable, awarding Hicks damages—estimated at 50% of the family’s requested “hundreds of thousands of pounds”—plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment, to cover rehabilitation and care. Both sides have the right to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final compensation amount.

Tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, Kansas (6 miles northwest of the city and less than 15 miles west of Wichita), and several near Aetna, Kansas (125 miles southwest of Wichita). A possible tornado also touched down in Potosi, Missouri (70 miles from St. Louis), causing wind damage and flooding. Severe storms and potential tornadoes are expected to continue across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most dangerous.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to fight in a middleweight clash with a potential title shot on the line. Rockhold, seeking his fourth consecutive win since a loss to Vitor Belfort, plans to aggressively pursue Machida and force him to fight his fight. He believes he has a significant advantage in all areas of mixed martial arts, particularly on the ground, and feels faster and more dynamic than Machida. Machida, also coming off a win, intends to utilize his style and technique to upset Rockhold and believes the winner of their fight deserves a title shot. Both fighters express respect for each other’s skills and preparation.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without its landing gear deployed, skidding along the tarmac. Despite the damage—including propellers hitting the runway—the pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, was able to take off again and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, landing safely with his dog. The incident, likely caused by pilot error or mechanical failure, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini is disappointed with Yaya Toure’s performance this season but will support him until the end of the season. The club will consider offers for Toure in the summer as they look to rebuild. City is also facing a poor run of form, with only 18 points from their last 39 available, and will be without captain Vincent Kompany due to injury. Additionally, City is interested in signing West Ham’s Aaron Cresswell, but Sam Allardyce has warned him about potentially limited playing time, citing the experiences of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the “Godfather of Uxbridge,” will be allowed to remain in the UK. He was originally sentenced to seven years in Italy in 1999 for mafia association but the sentence expired in October 2014 due to the length of time passed. Despite a previous extradition battle and concerns over Italian prison conditions due to his heart condition, the European Arrest Warrant will be withdrawn. The case was complicated by an administrative error from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) which delayed appealing a previous ruling, contributing to the sentence expiring. Rancadore had been living in the UK under an assumed name for over 20 years.

Mr Mole is a 7-2 co-favorite (along with Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre) in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This race will be AP McCoy’s last in a Grade One event, and his final day’s rides are still being finalized. McCoy announced his retirement after previously winning with Mr Mole at Newbury in February. There are six other runners in the chase, including Somersby. Sprinter Sacre will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty’s injury.

In 1975, Marcia Trimble Ritter was raped, choked, and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett. Her body was found 33 days after her disappearance, 150 yards from her home, and showed signs of sexual assault, strangulation, and blunt force trauma. For decades, her mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, declined to view crime scene photos, but finally did so last year and now seeks revenge. Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the murder, and in 2009, he was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison. The case had been Nashville’s most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years.

Rory McIlroy aims to win the Masters to complete a career grand slam, joining only five other golfers—Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods—to achieve this. He considers his 2011 Masters collapse the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. Despite past disappointments at Augusta (with only one top-10 finish in six appearances), McIlroy believes winning there is a career-long goal and feels it’s “unthinkable” he won’t win a green jacket eventually. He views the golf course as a “sanctuary” amidst personal and professional distractions, like a recent wedding cancellation and legal dispute.

This week’s trending stories include four rainbows appearing in New York, a crackdown on exotic dancers at wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr.’s reaction to personal questions in an interview, the #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend, a 102-year-old woman revisiting the past with filmmakers, a controversial prom-posal involving a bomb reference, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in “Beauty and the Beast,” Johnny Depp’s appearance in the “Black Mass” trailer, a “Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” themed pregnancy announcement, and a father photobombing his son.

In the past 12 months, 272 young people with foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in England. However, experts believe the actual number affected by prenatal alcohol exposure is much higher, potentially around 7,500 babies each year in the UK experiencing learning, behavioural, or physical problems. Foetal alcohol syndrome causes lifelong disabilities, and can also lead to issues with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Current government guidance advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption to a maximum of two units, twice a week, but some believe total abstinence should be recommended.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old with a history of re-offending (earning him the nickname “Boomerang Boy”), attempted to rob a post office in County Durham with an axe. The shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him, and his wife, Sam Dhillon, hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. Police arrested McKerry, who pleaded guilty and was sentenced to six years in jail. He had a long criminal record starting at age 12, including shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, and burglary.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—have been charged with sexual assault and group sexual assault following an incident at a Canadian barracks on April 10th. They have been granted bail with strict conditions: they must remain in Nova Scotia, surrender their passports, reside at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, continue working for the Royal Navy, and avoid contact with the victim and six witnesses. They are scheduled to return to court on May 27th and face up to 14 years in prison if convicted. The investigation is ongoing, and further charges are possible.

RJ Jackson, a four-year-old from Las Vegas, suffers from Netherton’s Syndrome, an incredibly rare skin disease affecting approximately 70 people worldwide. This condition causes his skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly, often mistaken for burns or abuse. Due to this, RJ’s mother, Valerie Jackson, has been reported to police for suspected child abuse and faces frequent, cruel comments and stares from the public. While there is no cure, the condition is managed with regular moisturization, and symptoms often improve with age. Mrs. Jackson found support and a diagnosis through an online Facebook group and emphasizes that despite his condition, RJ is a happy and beautiful boy.

The Protein World “Are you beach body ready?” advert, featuring model Renee Somerfield, was removed from London Underground stations after its three-week advertising period concluded. The advert sparked controversy and over 50,000 signatures on a change.org petition, with complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) exceeding 200, citing unhealthy body image promotion. While Protein World defended the campaign and reported receiving threats—including a bomb threat—and saw increased sales, Transport for London (TFL) will consider the public reaction if similar adverts are submitted in the future. The debate also played out on social media, with varied reactions ranging from outrage to support.

Following the general election, rail firms are planning fare hikes, with some increases reaching up to 87% starting May 17th. This is despite pledges from both main political parties to freeze or cap fare increases. Specifically, First Great Western (FGW) plans to nearly double some fares between London and the Cotswolds, impacting Prime Minister Cameron’s constituents, prompting his intervention. While some companies offer cheaper advance purchase options, unregulated fares—making up half of total revenue—are subject to these increases. Other examples include hikes on routes like Crewe to Northampton (London Midlands) and Stafford to Liverpool (Virgin). Virgin states most of their increases are on fares cheaper than competitors’ and their overall increase is 1.65%, below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown at his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The attack occurred while he and his wife, Elaine, 54, were writing thank you cards for their recent wedding (three weeks prior). Thugs initially threw stones at the house, and when Mr. Young went to confront them, a brick was thrown directly at him as he opened the door. Police are investigating but currently have no motive and suspect it may have been an act of vandalism. The couple are now moving due to feeling unsafe.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension through the end of the 2016 season following his successful recovery from leg injuries sustained in a road accident last April, in which his father died. He returned to play during a pre-season tour after undergoing an ankle operation, and Derbyshire’s elite performance director Graeme Welch expressed delight at his return and hopes the new contract will boost his confidence.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy, has been declared cancer-free after a year-long battle with neuroblastoma – a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. He underwent chemotherapy, an operation to remove a kidney tumour, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, using a Ninja Turtle mask to help him feel brave during treatment. Harley’s story gained attention, receiving support including gifts from Nickelodeon, and he is now a face for Cancer Research UK’s kids and teens campaign. He will continue with regular check-ups. Fewer than 100 children in the UK are diagnosed with neuroblastoma each year, and symptoms can include tiredness, pain, and difficulty with breathing or swallowing.

Tim Sherwood advises 19-year-old Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career to earn the opportunity to choose between playing for the Republic of Ireland or England internationally. Grealish recently impressed in a win against Liverpool and is currently undecided between the two countries. Both Sherwood and Grealish’s father, Kevin, agree that continued strong performances for Aston Villa should be his priority. He may have the opportunity to play for both countries in a friendly to help him decide.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The passage details the high landing fees at airports for private jets, a growing luxury travel market worth trillions in the US and Europe (with 2.5 million flights in the US in 2013). Landing fees can reach thousands of dollars, with the most expensive being Haneda Airport in Tokyo (£4,559/$6,850). Other expensive airports include Narita and Kansai in Japan, followed by Toronto, Darwin, Bristol, Dublin, La Guardia (New York), and Salzburg. These fees are particularly high during major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.

Katie Gallegos took her dogs, Cooper the Labrador and Daisy, to McDonald’s for ice cream and Starbucks for “pup-uccinos” (whipped cream in a cup). Daisy eats delicately, while Cooper quickly consumes his treat in one bite. A video of Cooper eating ice cream has been viewed over seven million times, sparking debate about feeding dogs ice cream, but Gallegos defends it, citing her previous dog’s similar treat and Cooper’s good health.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year deal. He initially joined as assistant manager last summer and took over as interim manager in February, achieving a record of one loss in seven games.

Jessica Kemp, a Florida mother, was threatened with a suspension for her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils (specifically doterra brand with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood) she applies to him for calming and focus. The school claimed the scent was a distraction, but the school district stated they would not suspend Logan, classifying it as a “health issue.” Kemp intends to continue using the oils, believing they positively impact her son.

On Wednesday at 3 pm, a fire destroyed a 90-condo beach-side apartment complex called the Sandpiper in Westhampton Beach. The fire was intense, melting paint off nearby buildings and visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews were unable to enter the building, which is used as a holiday home from May to November. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with claims it may have started near a parked car. The building manager and residents lost all their possessions.

The 88-year-old Queen recently enjoyed a ride on her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She has a lifelong love of horses, beginning with a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four, and continues to breed several breeds, including fell and highland ponies. Despite encouragement, she consistently chooses to ride without a helmet, preferring a silk scarf, citing her hairstyle. A recent knee injury has reduced her riding time, but she remains an enthusiastic equestrian. Fell ponies, like the Queen’s mount, are an ancient breed with a history stretching back to the Neolithic period and were valued by various cultures including the Romans and Vikings.

Leon Yeaman, 55, died after being punched by his neighbour, Phillip Pama, 28, during a noise dispute in North Brisbane. Pama has been charged with manslaughter. The argument began when Yeaman was making noise at 9 pm, disturbing Pama who was trying to sleep before a 3 am work shift. Pama’s lawyer stated the punch was thrown “blindly” during a confrontation, and Pama has no history of violence. Pama was granted bail with conditions including a curfew and passport surrender, and the case will return to court on May 18. Yeaman was described as generous but also as a schizophrenic pensioner who played loud music.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the act, detailing specific injuries she wanted inflicted. However, the plan was uncovered by a police sting operation, with an undercover officer posing as a hitman and recording her instructions. Simonova was arrested and now faces 15 years in prison on attempted murder charges. Vanya expressed relief at her arrest and hoped for a lengthy prison sentence.

José Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, prays daily but keeps his faith separate from his work, never discussing football with God or his wife. He and his family are aware of poverty and work with the World Food Programme to fight hunger. Despite a competitive and emotional professional life, Mourinho believes he is a good person and values his family and friendships. Chelsea is currently leading the league and will play QPR this weekend; Mourinho was recently fined for comments about a perceived campaign against the team.

Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to host the first game ("Lucky Seven") on the April 1st episode after an eight-year absence, before Drew Carey finished hosting the show. Barker, age 91, appeared capable despite his time away from the show.

Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested on Friday at 12:30 am for attempted burglary and destruction of property at a residence on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington D.C. He has been placed on leave and had his security clearance revoked. This arrest follows another incident involving a high-ranking supervisor on leave due to misconduct allegations, and another investigation into agency officials driving into a secure White House area.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to photograph a male lion at the city’s safari park. He exited his car and approached the lion to within 10 feet, lying on the ground to capture the image. The camera's shutter sound alerted the lion, causing Saeed to quickly retreat to his car as the lion aggressively approached him. He described the experience as a close encounter he likely wouldn’t repeat.

An unidentified woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, died on March 22nd in Brooklyn near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. She had no identification but had a distinctive heart tattoo on her right leg with the name “Monique” inside. Police are asking for public assistance in identifying her and are awaiting a medical examiner’s report to determine the cause of death; tips can be submitted to NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a two-bedroom, solar-powered home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK and being unable to afford property. The year-and-a-half project cost approximately $25,000 and allows them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand, utilizing solar power and water from a nearby spring. They enjoy a cozy, wood-lined home surrounded by nature.

Research indicates kindergarten children who *share* iPads in class outperform those with individual iPads or no iPads on early literacy tests, scoring around 30 points higher. This suggests collaborative learning *around* the technology is key to improved results, according to Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University, who studied 352 students. The findings challenge skepticism about technology in non-IT classes and suggest schools should reconsider iPad usage in early grades.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its front two trotters. The piglet, nicknamed “Super Pig,” maintains its balance while foraging for food and interacts with its four-legged siblings. Its owner, Ms. Duan, noticed the piglet’s condition at birth. This is not the first such case in China, as a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also gained popularity for its unique way of moving.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured when struck by the car of Francesco Dracone on lap 25 as Dracone exited his pit box. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut and was released from the infield care center. Dracone, a 19-year-old from Italy, spun out and finished 23rd. Rain prior to the race caused traction issues for many drivers.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena (also known as Amanda Bueno), 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, just four days after their marriage. He smashed her head against concrete 11 times and shot her in the face five times, confessing he was motivated by jealousy over men looking at her. He was arrested after crashing a stolen car during his escape, and police found multiple weapons and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He now faces life in jail. Cicera Alves de Sena was a dancer in the dance troop Jaula das Gostozuedas.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author, recently revealed her struggle with anxiety and mental illness, stating she once felt life wasn’t worth living. This was due to a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation. Wilson believes anxiety and depression are linked and is becoming increasingly prevalent, particularly among Australian women (one in three will experience anxiety). She now accepts she is an anxious person and encourages seeking help via Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

In November 2014, Elena Curtin, who was seven-months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault after hitting her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and, after she refused to leave, attacked her. Prosecutors dropped the charges, stating Curtin was “completely justified in her outrage” due to Oregon law allowing physical force against intruders. The ex-girlfriend had previously harassed Curtin and attempted to pull the boyfriend back into heroin use. Curtin has since given birth and is living with her parents, while the boyfriend is not involved in the child’s life.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust to being given broccoli despite enjoying treats and time with her family. She spat the broccoli out, and her owner hopes the children she lives with will still eat their vegetables.

HSBC apologized after a link on its website directed users to a pornographic page. This occurred because the link, formerly for the Young Entrepreneur Awards (scrapped in 2011), was allowed to expire and was taken over by a pornographic website. HSBC removed the link and stated they have no association with the external site, apologizing for any inconvenience. They also confirmed their website and internet banking services remain secure.

On Sunday morning, a fire broke out on the first floor of a home in Clinton, Maryland. A 13-year-old boy, Marcus, called 911 and guided firefighters to rescue himself and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, who were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus also calmed his sister during the 11-minute call. All five family members—Marcus, Aaliyah, his mother, stepfather, and older brother—were rescued; the siblings were treated for non-life-threatening injuries. Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward was particularly heroic in the rescue.

Blue fluorescent algae are illuminating the east coast of Australia, recently observed in Jervis Bay and previously in Sydney’s Manly Beach in 2014. The glow is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that emits light as a defense mechanism when it preys on diatoms. Experts, like Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, state the phenomenon is natural and poses no concern, typically occurring in spring and autumn.

New genetic tests, like Endopredict, can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and predict the risk of recurrence after surgery. These tests can allow some patients to avoid chemotherapy – a treatment with difficult side effects – if their risk of recurrence is low (as little as 5%). Currently, these tests are mostly private (costing around £2,500), but experts hope they will become available on the NHS, as the cost of the test may be offset by savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy.

Over the last nine years, more than 25 Royal Navy sailors have been airlifted from ships due to pregnancy, including at least one from HMS Illustrious and five from HMS Ocean. Additionally, 99 servicewomen were flown back from operations (including 16 from Afghanistan in 2013 and 102 from Iraq) between 2006-2013. The Ministry of Defence maintains a “no touching” rule, suggesting conceptions occurred before deployment or during leave. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and comprised 9% of personnel in 2014.

A drone containing traces of cesium, a radioactive material, was found on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence. Police are investigating the origin of the drone, which also contained a camera and smoke flares. The discovery raises terrorism concerns, particularly regarding potential threats to the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. Current Japanese law has limited drone flight restrictions, and Abe was in Indonesia at the time of the incident. The amount of radiation detected is not currently harmful to humans.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer’s, to work with him daily on his motorbike due to fears of her getting lost. He secures her with a sash during the hour-long, four-kilometre journey and his employer provides her with a room at work. He feels obligated to care for her as she devoted her life to caring for him and his siblings.

Between 2005 and 2012, heavy drinking in the US increased by 17.2%, primarily driven by rising rates among women. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers (defined as 4+ drinks for women and 5+ for men on one occasion). The study, tracking drinking patterns at the county level using data from over 3.7 million adults, links the increase to changing social norms for women, increased alcohol advertising ($3.45 billion in 2011), weakening alcohol control policies, and alcohol becoming cheaper. Excessive drinking was linked to approximately 88,600 deaths and over $220 billion in costs in 2010.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing too many caesarean sections, putting women and babies at risk. While potentially life-saving, the procedure is often done without medical need, leading to complications, disability, or even death, and diverting funds from other patients. Currently, over 25% of births in England are via caesarean – more than double the rate in the early 1990s – while the WHO recommends a rate of 10-15%. A planned caesarean costs the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for a natural birth, and can cause infections in up to one in ten cases. Current NHS guidelines, however, contradict the WHO’s stance by offering the procedure even without medical justification, particularly for women with tokophobia or certain medical conditions/birth histories.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17th after allegedly breaking into a summer home in Edgartown, Martha’s Vineyard, and living there for at least a week. She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Filkins reportedly sold items from the home in a yard sale and fled when the owner, Mark Conklin, discovered her. Police are seeking the return of stolen items, including furniture, cookware, and a painting, and consider purchasers of these items to be victims eligible for restitution. Her next court date is May 14th.

Police in Albury, on the NSW-Victoria border, used Bella Crooke’s unlocked iPhone to post humorous selfies and updates on her Facebook page after it was handed in to the station. They did this to locate her after she lost the phone at a friend’s birthday party. Friends quickly recognised Bella, and she reclaimed her phone without needing to provide identification, amused by the police’s actions and their replies to messages from her friends. Bella has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the isimangaliso wetland park, eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water surface, and died hours later. The mother hippopotamus watched helplessly, having stayed with her herd believing it was the safest place for her, but one of the adults grabbed the calf. A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the event.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is for sale at £575,000 – significantly lower than comparable properties – but has only three years remaining on its lease. The property, described as “bright and well proportioned” with 1,990 sq/ft of space, requires modernisation. Extending the lease could increase its value to upwards of £6 million, but this would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The current owner is Russell Simpson, and the freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust. Similar properties with short leases are rare, generating significant interest despite the upcoming election.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores (7,000 in the US and 1,000 in Canada) on Friday evening, disrupting sales and preventing credit card transactions. This led many baristas to give away free drinks, which was widely shared on social media. Some stores closed to avoid further giveaways. The outage, caused by a failure during a system refresh, has been resolved and stores are expected to operate normally on Saturday. Starbucks, which has 21,366 locations in 65 countries, recently posted record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion.

West Wales—specifically Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire—is being used for terrorist training and radicalization of Muslims. This activity dates back to at least 1998 and has involved individuals linked to attacks such as the 7/7 bombings and the murder of Lee Rigby. These individuals often participate in normal activities while secretly planning attacks, and community intelligence is crucial for authorities. The Brecon Beacons and a country park are specifically mentioned as locations used for these purposes.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

An Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct, was discovered on a beach in Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. Identified through DNA profiling, the find is significant as the species was only scientifically described in 2003 and little is known about it. The whale’s skeleton will be recovered for research and potential museum display. Omura's whales are typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, and have a sleek body with unique skeletal features like 53 vertebrae.

This passage discusses the bias against women in leadership, specifically in the context of the 2015 presidential election and Hillary Clinton’s candidacy. It highlights how some, like businesswoman Cheryl Rios, believe a woman’s hormones disqualify her from being president, while others suggest postmenopausal women are *better* suited for the role. The core argument is that despite progress, a significant gender bias persists—both overt and covert—that creates obstacles for women in the workplace and politics. The author argues that equality benefits everyone, boosting economies, families, and teams, and that addressing this bias is crucial for allowing women to reach their full potential.

Actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in “All Creatures Great and Small” and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 antiques due to downsizing his home. The auction, taking place Saturday at Dominic Winter in Gloucestershire, includes items like a 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000-£6,000), furniture by Gillows of Lancaster (up to £4,000), a longbow, and paintings. Mr. Hardy, 89, is a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, having studied with J.R.R. Tolkien and published books on the subject. The total estimated value of the auction is £100,000.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their Winter Garden, Florida home on Saturday. He failed to appear for a scheduled visit with his son and has a history of bipolar mental illness, prior arrest for battery on law enforcement, and a previous suicide attempt. Neighbors believe the murder may be linked to his ongoing divorce and a recent unfavorable legal development, with his mother potentially intervening to prevent complications with his son's custody. He was last seen fleeing on foot without medication and authorities are seeking information on his whereabouts (407-656-3636).

Eugene, USA will host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a “unique strategic opportunity” to hold the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously bid for the 2019 event but lost to Doha, Qatar. The decision was also made without a bidding process for the 2007 championships in Osaka, Japan.

Leonie Granger, 25, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger befriended Hassan at a casino, and then facilitated a robbery at his flat by leaving the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29. Jackson and Chandler then beat Hassan to death while searching for his hidden winnings – estimated to be kept around his flat, even in his microwave – and were both sentenced to life in prison with a minimum of 36 years for murder. All three were also convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan. The attack was described as “pitiless and wicked.”

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has experienced a decline in form after a strong start to the season. Previously on track to break the Premier League assist record, his performance has significantly dropped, particularly since Christmas, a trend noted by his former club Barcelona. While Chelsea is likely to win the Premier League, concerns remain about Fabregas’s endurance during a demanding season. Manager Jose Mourinho hopes Fabregas can regain his form, as his contributions are crucial for Chelsea to secure the title.

West Ham are in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial with the club. He has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered a promising talent. Additionally, West Ham announced season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the lowest price in the Premier League, to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Mike Lane, a 40-year-old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was violently assaulted by protesters with iron bars while the hunt followed an artificial scent on January 24th. Despite video evidence, names, and car registration numbers provided to Wiltshire Police, the investigation has been dropped due to “insufficient evidence.” Lane suffered concussion, broken teeth, memory loss, and required £500 in dental treatment. The Countryside Alliance is now campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs to aid in identifying criminals. Wiltshire Police state the case is currently “undetected” but could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was a U.S. citizen and prominent Al Qaeda propagandist killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. He converted to Islam in 1995 and traveled to Pakistan in 1998 to join Al Qaeda, becoming their chief English-language propagandist. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support of Al Qaeda and was on the FBI’s “Most Wanted Terrorists” list. Another U.S. citizen, Ahmed Farouq, also died in a separate operation, and his death coincided with the deaths of two hostages, Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto. Gadahn was married with at least one child and had a role in Al Qaeda’s media strategy, evidenced by a letter found in Osama bin Laden’s compound.

Mai Zizhuo, a five-year-old boy in China, has become a viral sensation due to his exceptional basketball skills. He began playing at two and a half years old and is now gaining a large fanbase, with many impressed by his abilities – including dribbling two basketballs simultaneously and consistently making shots. This has led to comparisons to Yao Ming, China’s biggest basketball star, and reactions of disbelief and self-doubt from online viewers.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) – a group that campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s – has joined supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally at Parliament on February 25th to lobby MPs for state media regulation. Hacked Off is campaigning for a statutory body to regulate the press, following recommendations from the Leveson Inquiry, and opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation. O'Carroll was previously jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals.”

Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday for a Ten Pieces fashion show during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The show featured a monochrome, unisex collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 ways. Guests enjoyed food and drinks while watching models walk the empty pool and break wall, with the ocean as a backdrop, on a warm 28°C day. The brand, Ten Pieces, is headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent Friday at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. They posed with giraffes and sea lions, and Khan fed a white tiger. He recently announced he will fight Chris Algieri on May 30th, despite pressure to fight Kell Brook.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian, was mistakenly included on an Israeli memorial wall for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His family and Almagor, an organization for victims of terror, objected to his inclusion, arguing he was not a terror victim and no permission was sought from his family. The National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove his name from the memorial following these complaints, and it has already been removed from the memorial website. Three Israelis are on trial for his murder.

A young boy repeatedly tried to use the family cat as a pillow in their garden, following the cat to new locations each time. The cat eventually went inside to avoid being used as a pillow, but the boy and cat later reconciled with the boy giving the cat treats. The incident was filmed and posted to YouTube by the boy’s father, Lionel Hutz.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves testimony from over a dozen former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner. Kushner testified that officers stole $81,000 and marijuana from him in 2007, but also has a history of drug offenses and a 2008 DUI. As a result of his testimony, he lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy. The defense argues the case relies on unreliable testimony from drug dealers and a former rogue officer. Six officers are accused of racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping, and drug dealing.

An explosion and fire occurred at a paraxylene (px) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, China, injuring six people—five from broken glass. The fire, which started after an oil leak, is now under control thanks to over 600 firefighters. The plant previously experienced an explosion in 2013 and faced protests in 2007 due to pollution concerns, leading to its relocation. Px is a chemical used to make polyester and is reportedly carcinogenic.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, intentionally wears his socks low, just above his shinpads, due to superstition—a habit he’s maintained throughout his life. He also uses children’s size shinpads. Despite being asked by referees to pull his socks up, he intends to continue playing this way, having made his first Premier League start against QPR in a 3-3 draw and hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has sustained “global and irreversible brain damage” and remains unresponsive after nearly three months. While her father, Bobby Brown, stated she is awake and watching him, her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and a source confirm she is still in the same neurological state, does not respond to stimuli, and has a tracheostomy. Despite this, the family’s attorney states doctors indicate she will have a long life, but the quality of that life is currently unknown as she begins a lengthy rehabilitation process.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in their Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova beat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova’s straight-sets win over Julia Goerges. Russia now needs one win from the remaining matches to reach the final and win their first title since 2008. Both Pavlyuchenkova and Lisicki struggled with their serve, with Pavlyuchenkova having 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors.

New South Wales residents are bracing for another potential storm and floods this week, following severe weather last week. An east coast low is predicted to bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, particularly impacting the state’s north east, northern rivers, and mid north coast, with possible effects in southeast Queensland. The State Emergency Service (SES) has over 4,000 outstanding requests from last week and is concerned the new storm will hamper clean-up efforts, especially in the hard-hit Hunter region. They are urging residents to prepare. While the system is expected to move quickly and may not be as severe as last week’s, further rainfall is likely in already flooded catchments. Over 1000 SES personnel are currently deployed across NSW, including support from other states.

Nina Moric, a model known for appearing in a Ricky Martin music video, addressed reports that she attempted suicide. She stated she collapsed at home due to low blood pressure and was treated in hospital for bruising, denying claims she tried to end her life. Her boyfriend initially suggested she had tried to commit suicide, but later stated he was in Naples at the time of the incident. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a paparazzi who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, with whom she has a son.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

The British public anticipates the birth of Kate and William’s second child, with a preference for a girl (desired by 25% of those polled). The most popular name choice for a girl is Diana (12%), in honor of William’s mother, followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each). If a boy, James (13%) and Alexander are favored. Additionally, 68% of people support William taking six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan (Khost city) on Thursday, killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack. The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor.

Dani Alves will leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting their final contract offer. He has spent seven successful years with the club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles. The proposed three-year extension required him to play in 60% of matches, which was unacceptable to Alves and his agent/ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, who stated negotiations are now over.

Pablo Osvaldo wants Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes their playing styles would suit the Argentinian club and the fans would be enthusiastic about their arrival. He has scored three goals in six games since joining Boca on loan from Southampton.

Lee Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton, resulting in a viral video online. He sustained only a cut on his nose and was back riding the next day, undeterred. He described the fall as a "blur" and expressed luckiness regarding the outcome, also noting the humorous reaction from fellow jockeys and gaining new Twitter followers. He jokingly considered a career in gymnastics.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man to coincide with the release of “Avengers: Age of Ultron.” The movie premiered at Westfield London on Tuesday, featuring stars like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell previously played for Wasps from 2002-2009, then had stints in France (Stade Francais), Japan (Ricoh Black Rams), and New Zealand (Highlanders) before returning to Wasps in 2012, where he has since played over 100 games and earned 57 England caps.

The wide-leg trouser is a key trend for Spring/Summer 2015 (SS15), offering an alternative to skinny jeans which have been popular for years. It’s a look that has returned from the 1970s, seen on runways like Gucci and Celine. 

To wear it well, especially if shorter, pair wide legs with high heels (particularly those that expose the top of the foot) and a simple top – a knit, shirt, or tee – to maintain proportion. Denim is the easiest way to try the trend, with options available from brands like Gucci and Topshop. Longer lengths should be high-waisted.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a screening of “American Sniper” after initially cancelling it due to student objections. Over 200 students petitioned against the film, citing negative portrayals of the Middle East, particularly given the large Arab-American population in the Detroit area. However, this decision faced backlash, and the university reversed course, citing a commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. A screening of “Paddington” will also be offered as an alternative.

Two French tourists (aged 18 and 24, residing in Cockburn Central) ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to contact a quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia on April 3rd. The quokka survived but was singed. The men were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17th. Quokkas are about the size of a domestic cat and are found on islands off the west Australian coast, including Rottnest Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club in the 1930s and 40s, recently saw herself dancing for the first time. Despite performing with stars like Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra and being filmed, she had never seen the footage and lost all her photos. Filmmakers compiled "soundies" (early music videos) to show her, and she was delighted by the experience.

A study of 1,100 UK adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV reveals a decline in car owners washing their own vehicles. One third of men and three-quarters of women have *never* washed their own car, with most preferring car washes. Factors include increased Sunday activities, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicle sizes. Car washing is most common during holidays and in cities like Birmingham, Sheffield and Chelmsford, and most frequent for Audis, Toyotas and BMWs.

Steven Gerrard is set to leave Liverpool after the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with the potential to play in the final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30th, before joining LA Galaxy. Martin Skrtel praises Gerrard’s positive impact on his career since 2008 and considers him one of the best players in the world, synonymous with Liverpool. While acknowledging Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, Skrtel believes the club has players who can replace him. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are eligible to play against Aston Villa after serving bans.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, achieved a hole-in-one on the fourth hole (130-yard) during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first ace at Augusta, though Camilo Villegas also had two aces that day, contributing to a record-tying five hole-in-ones during the contest. Kevin Streelman ultimately won the contest in a playoff. Nicklaus previously won the Masters six times (first in 1963, most recently in 1986) and is a career Grand Slam winner.

Tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, Kansas (6 miles northwest of the city, less than 17 miles west of Wichita) and near Aetna, Kansas (125 miles southwest of Wichita). A possible tornado also touched down in Potosi, Missouri (70 miles from St. Louis), causing wind damage and flooding. Severe weather, including baseball-sized hail, was also reported in Farmington, Missouri. More storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most dangerous.

Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve sheriff’s deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the shooting death of Eric Harris. Bates claims he intended to use a taser but mistakenly shot Harris with a gun during an arrest in a weapons sting operation. The judge granted Bates permission to travel to the Bahamas for vacation, which Harris’s family criticized as showing apathy. Bates’s lawyers state he was properly trained, while the Harris family’s lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment due to donations and a friendship with the sheriff; allegations the sheriff’s office denies. Two deputies have been reassigned due to threats. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2nd.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight champion title in Las Vegas on July 11th. Aldo is defending his belt for the eighth time. McGregor recently got a tiger tattoo on his stomach and has publicly stated he believes Aldo lacks the same motivation to fight as he has to win the title, demonstrated by an incident where McGregor took Aldo’s belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Tony Abbott received criticism for quickly drinking (“skolling”) a beer at an Australian Rules function. Critics, like cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argue this glorifies binge drinking and reinforces a harmful association between masculinity and heavy alcohol consumption, especially given current concerns about binge drinking. While some, like Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott, pointing to his fitness, others felt he should set a better example. Abbott’s act evoked comparisons to former Prime Minister Bob Hawke’s similar displays, but was viewed differently due to changed attitudes towards heavy drinking.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, linked to intravenous drug use—specifically the painkiller Opana. This is a substantial increase from the typical five cases per year. A 30-day needle exchange program was approved by Governor Mike Pence on March 26th, and has so far provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with 1,400 used syringes returned. Governor Pence is currently deciding whether to extend the program beyond April 25th, despite his general opposition to needle exchanges. Legislation to allow similar programs in other counties is also being considered, but faces funding and political hurdles.

An Arsenal fan created a detailed, school-exam-style test for his girlfriend, Saskia, about the football club. She scored 87% (43.5/50), which was enough to avoid being “dumped” according to her boyfriend. The test included multiple-choice questions, open-ended answers, and questions about players, positions, and club history. While impressed with her score, her boyfriend provided critical feedback. The event gained attention on Twitter, with some users praising the boyfriend as a “legend” and Saskia as “proper gf material,” while others thought the boyfriend had gone too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as a DEA informant for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. He provided crucial information leading to the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, the DEA has not helped him obtain citizenship, and he is now facing deportation while living in the US illegally due to declining health and a lapsed visa. He fears for his life if returned to Colombia and is currently seeking legal status.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh. She is currently hospitalized with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested. This incident occurs amidst heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following a recent ban on a documentary about a previous gang rape case and several instances of vigilante justice against alleged rapists, including beatings and deaths. The earlier case involved Jyoti Singh, a 23-year-old student who died after being gang-raped on a bus in Delhi, sparking widespread protests and resulting in death sentences for some of her attackers.

Louis van Gaal, the Manchester United manager, is preparing for the derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday. Despite some players declaring fitness, Van Gaal has ruled out both Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, stating they aren’t yet at the required match fitness level. A win against City could see United finish as high as third in the league, avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal emphasizes the importance of controlling aggression, learning from their previous 1-0 loss to City, and acknowledges City will be a tough opponent. He is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere with the support of United fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested high ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match. This action followed the announcement of a £5.14 billion TV rights deal, with fans expressing outrage over prices—starting at £64 for this match—they deem “extortionate.” Supporters from both clubs, organized by groups like the Black Scarf Movement and Spirit of Shankly, argue that rising costs threaten the future of attending matches for working-class fans and that football is prioritizing money over its supporters. Further protests are planned after the game.

Star, a newborn baby, was diagnosed with biliary atresia – a life-threatening liver condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent – shortly after birth. Initial attempts to unblock her ducts were unsuccessful, and she required a liver transplant. Neither of her parents were suitable donors, but her maternal aunt and her mother’s twin sister, Shanell, was a match and donated part of her liver, saving Star’s life. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since recovered well, though she requires ongoing medication and monitoring.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in an Audi football challenge involving skill-based tasks with Audi cars. Hazard and Ake initially led with wins in close-range and “tennis net” (using an Audi R8) challenges. Remy and Willian won the final long-range shooting challenge, but Willian accidentally broke an Audi’s wing mirror during the game. Despite the mishap, no one was required to pay for the damage.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, was sentenced after pleading guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of Amanda Murphy (24, eight months pregnant) and Jason Timmons (29) on December 7, 2013. Dellinger drove his truck across a highway median at over 100mph, colliding with their SUV and killing them and their unborn baby, Reagan Elizabeth. While prosecutors initially stated Dellinger said he intended to kill himself, he claimed in court he was not suicidal. His defense cited ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, prozac, and multiple sclerosis as contributing factors. He faces 12-24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt through his feeding tube. The boy’s father, Chris Hill, expressed anger and a desire for her to face hardship in prison on Facebook. Prosecutors argued Spears intentionally harmed her son for attention, while her lawyer maintains her innocence and plans to appeal, blaming hospital negligence. The judge acknowledged Spears suffers from a mental illness but described the crime as “unfathomable in its cruelty.” Spears continued to blog throughout the ordeal and showed no emotion during sentencing.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Australia will receive an improved influenza vaccine a month later than expected, offering protection against four strains including H3N2 and B/Phuket – strains that caused increased deaths in Europe and the US due to a poor vaccine match in the northern hemisphere. Free, government-funded shots will be available to high-risk groups (young children, the elderly, and most Indigenous Australians) from April 20th, but all individuals are encouraged to get vaccinated. Experts believe this updated vaccine is a better match to circulating global strains and will help prevent deaths.

Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield, Illinois is facing challenges including a negative review in *National Geographic*—describing it as lacking historical character—and potential budget cuts from the state of Illinois, which could impact its management. Despite over $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations, including upgrades to the interior and waterproofing of the receiving vault, the tomb has experienced reduced hours and staffing due to previous funding cuts. The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has been reconstructed twice and features a distinctive interior of marble and bronze. While some, like the *National Geographic* author, are critical, others find the site impressive.

The passage discusses the return of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends. While some styles like chokers and berry-coloured lips are currently popular, the potential comeback of Jcno jeans has sparked debate. The article highlights several trends that may be better left in the past, including bucket hats, camouflage print, extreme styles (like double denim), Ugg boots, tiny denim shorts ("Daisy Dukes"), Juicy Couture tracksuits, coloured sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. It contrasts how these trends were worn by celebrities in the past (like Britney Spears, Paris Hilton, and Victoria Beckham) with how they are being revisited by current celebrities (like Rihanna, Kylie Jenner, and Nicki Minaj).

This week's trending stories include: four rainbows appearing in New York, a crackdown on exotic dancers at wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr.'s frustration with personal questions in an interview, the #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend, a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past with filmmakers, a controversial prom-posal, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer, a "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" themed pregnancy announcement, and a father photobombing his son.

The Miami Open has featured multiple celebrations for player achievements. Serena Williams reached her 700th career victory and advanced to the semi-finals after defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3). Andy Murray was also recently celebrated for his 500th win. Williams will now face Simona Halep in the semi-finals, after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens (6-1, 7-5). Venus Williams was defeated by Carla Suarez Navarro, preventing a potential match-up with her sister, Serena.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani cafe owner and activist, was shot and killed in Karachi after hosting a discussion about human rights issues in Baluchistan, a region facing separatist conflict and allegations of mass abduction. She was known for openly discussing sensitive topics like politics, human rights, and women’s entrepreneurship—a dangerous act in Pakistan—and had received death threats previously. Her cafe, “The Second Floor” (T2F), was a haven for those seeking freedom of thought and progressive values, and her death has sparked grief and a sense of loss for those who valued her work. No one has claimed responsibility for the shooting.

For 70 years, approximately 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), primarily Hindu, have lived as second-class citizens in Indian Kashmir. They fled to the region following the 1947 partition of India but have been denied citizenship rights – including the ability to own property or vote – due to political sensitivities around the state’s Muslim-majority demographic. Despite most never having lived in Pakistan, they remain classified as refugees. Recent gains by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in state elections have given the WPRs hope for change, with the BJP expected to advocate for their rights. However, activists warn the community may resort to protest if their demands are not met.

Chelsea has made a £4 million offer for FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, but he is considering whether to accept. While Chelsea may loan him to Vitesse Arnhem, Muto wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledges Muto and admits commercial interests, like their sponsorship deal with a Japanese company, can influence transfer decisions, but insists they only pursue good players. Former manager Ranko Popovic believes Muto has “amazing” potential and is a uniquely intelligent and confident player.

Australia has changed its policy to allow players based overseas to be selected for the national team, prompting criticism of England’s continued stance of not selecting overseas players. The author argues England should follow suit, citing examples of players like Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, Jonny Wilkinson, Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell who have improved playing abroad. The core argument is that England should select its best possible team for the upcoming World Cup, regardless of where players are based, to maximize their chances of winning.

Open Garden developed the Firechat app, which allows users to chat without a web or mobile signal by utilizing a phone’s Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct to create a wireless mesh network. This app has been downloaded over five million times. To extend the range of these networks (currently limited to around 200ft/61m), Open Garden created Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon/booster. Greenstone currently works within a 20ft/6m range with Firechat, stores up to 1,000 messages, and has a one-year battery life. It’s designed for use in areas with poor connectivity, like planes or crowded events, and aims to provide resilient communication. Greenstone is currently under development and awaiting manufacturing partnerships.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, is working to reclaim the word "fat" as a neutral, body-positive descriptor. She points out that "fat," like "short" or "wife," is simply a factual description. Despite this, size discrimination has risen 66% in the past 30 years, and young girls often wish to be thinner. However, exposure to body diversity increases acceptance of different body types, and Bustle uses burlesque to showcase a positive, glamorous "fat" body. Her TED Talk, posted online recently, has received largely positive feedback and inspired many, including a teenage girl who reevaluated her body image after watching it.

Theo Walcott and six of his Arsenal teammates (Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil) participated in a photoshoot with runway model Olga Sherer for Lanvin, Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013. Walcott, 26, has spent much of the season on the bench, being named a substitute in 17 of 33 Premier League games, and hopes to start in the upcoming game against Hull after last playing from the start on March 14th. The team will wear similar attire to the photoshoot at the FA Cup final on May 30th.

A collection of over 400 props and puppets from the 30-year career of make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off on May 29th at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, from Baker’s Cinovation studio, is estimated to be worth $746,100, with individual items potentially exceeding $40,000. Items from films like *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2*, *Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker*, and *Mighty Joe Young* will be included.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell from Wales died in a skiing accident in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother and sister while skiing. He entered dense woodland, believing he could reach the resort, and fell 164ft. He was a “daring, outgoing, and determined” boy who loved skiing, snowboarding, and modeled himself after Bear Grylls. His family describes being utterly devastated by the loss. Carwyn was a popular pupil at Ysol y Bannau school and came from a family known for their award-winning farm shop.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after being bullied about her weight and feeling pressure to be a “size zero.” Over two years, her eating disorder led her to restrict her diet to as little as one piece of fruit a day, hiding food from her parents and obsessively counting calories. This resulted in a dangerously slowed heart rate and eventual collapse, requiring a week on a heart monitor in intensive care. She has since received support from eating disorder organizations and is now in recovery, with improved body image and a place as a semi-finalist in Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive body image. Anorexia is described as a serious mental health condition, affecting around 725,000 people in the UK (10% with anorexia specifically) and often stemming from anxiety about body shape or weight.

Liverpool unveiled their new 2015/16 home kit, designed by New Balance in a record-breaking £300million four-year deal, at an event at Anfield. Players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, and Martin Skrtel modeled the kit, with fans expressing their desire for Sterling to remain at the club. Despite recently rejecting a £100,000-a-week contract and being linked with Arsenal, Liverpool are confident Sterling will stay. The team is also focused on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, with hopes of winning the cup as a stepping stone to future success. The kit includes a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster with the memorial flame and number 96.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Researchers at the University of Manchester have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter to date, covering 0.4% of the night sky. This map, created using data from the Dark Energy Survey’s Dark Energy Camera, visualizes dark matter’s gravitational effects on galaxies (red indicates more dark matter, blue less). The project aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, ultimately creating a 3D view of dark matter and dark energy. Dark matter is estimated to comprise at least 80-85% of the matter in the universe and is studied through its gravitational lensing effect on light. The map supports the theory that galaxies form in areas with high concentrations of dark matter.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV win the Dutch Eredivisie title for the first time in seven years. He previously worked with Van Gaal during the 2014 World Cup. Other clubs, including Tottenham and Paris Saint-Germain, have also shown interest, but PSV expect a “bigger amount of money” than Tottenham’s previous £15 million offer. Scouts believe Depay, a pacy and skillful winger, has the potential to rival Cristiano Ronaldo, and is already more developed than Ronaldo was at the same age.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth side 3-1 in the Youth Cup final, securing a 3-1 aggregate lead. Tammy Abraham scored a first-half double (his 35th and 36th goals of the season), and Dominic Solanke added a third late in the game. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored to briefly level the match. The game also featured performances from several promising young players on both sides, including Chelsea’s Ola Aina and Jake Clarke-Salter, and City’s Tosin Adarabioyo and Brandon Barker. An injury to Tammy Abraham during the match is a concern for Chelsea.

Marco Rubio believes people are born with their sexual preference but maintains that marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman. He doesn’t believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and thinks states should regulate marriage through legislation, not court decisions. Despite his beliefs, he would attend the same-sex wedding of a loved one. He recently announced his candidacy for president and has secured over $51 million in financial commitments.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are cycling around the world with no set plans, having quit their jobs in Manchester. In their first 356 days, they’ve travelled almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting in London and travelling through Europe to Armenia. They live on less than €3 per day (€0.10 per kilometre) by camping (161 nights), using hosting websites (Couchsurfing & Warmshowers), and relying on inexpensive food like pasta, rice, and seasonal produce – sometimes supplemented by gifts or foraged food. Their next goal is to continue into Asia, cross the Pacific, and cycle the length of the American continent.

In 2012, a couple from Texas hired Premiere Photos for a photo booth at their wedding. They are now suing the owner, James Evans, alleging that the photo booth printed racial slurs on the photos. Evans reportedly told the couple to “sue” him and has denied the allegations, claiming a lack of evidence and that the couple showed no distress. The couple, represented by attorney Cathy Hale, seeks an apology and is pursuing the case under the Texas deceptive trade practices act, citing negligence and breach of contract. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if no agreement is reached.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Several rugby players are currently dealing with concussions. Mike Brown (Harlequins & England) is being cautious with his return after a concussion following the France game and a previous knockout in February against Italy, aided by increased concussion awareness from World Rugby modules. George North (Northampton) has been advised to end his season after four concussions, and Johnny Sexton (Ireland) was previously sidelined for 12 weeks. Brown emphasizes the importance of recognizing symptoms and not risking long-term health, even when facing important matches. The summary is part of a Land Rover campaign promoting grassroots rugby.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

Research indicates a decline in sexual frequency among Britons since the emergence of the internet. Currently, a typical heterosexual couple has sex three times a month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter suggests increased smartphone and technology use, leading to busier lives and blurred boundaries between work/home life, is a key factor in this decline, alongside a rise in people living alone. People are prioritizing other things and remaining too connected to focus on their partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, once status symbols in China selling for up to £1.2 million each, have become deeply unpopular and are now being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin. This decline is attributed to a Chinese government anti-corruption crackdown (as they were previously gifted to officials) and new dog weight restrictions in major cities. The market is also flooded with poor-quality dogs due to breeders prioritizing profit over breed standards, and increasing urbanization has led to the realization that they are not suited to city living. Animal welfare concerns are rising, with reports of dogs being found in cramped, inhumane conditions during transport to abattoirs, and instances of theft from the streets.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area revealed that **every woman** has experienced some form of **sexual harassment on public transport**, with **half** experiencing it **before the age of 18**. This harassment ranges from **verbal insults to physical and sexual assault**. As a result, **six out of ten women fear attacks** on public transport, leading them to **alter their routines** to avoid confrontation and limiting their freedom. The report calls for a **campaign to address sexist behaviour** and **educate both victims and aggressors** about what constitutes sexual assault and its consequences.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd. He states he is fit and ready to run, and aims to make Jamaica proud, continuing the country’s successful relay tradition. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.
